clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Autologous Mesenchymal Stem Cell Transplantation in Chronic Spinal Cord Injury: a Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to analyze the safety and efficacy of mesenchymal stem cell transplantation through percutaneous injection in patients with chronic spinal cord injury.

primary_outcome.description: After the transplantation of the cells, patients will be followed up by clinical examinations and will perform laboratorial and radiological exams, in order to search for complications of the procedure.

secondary_outcome.measure: Sensitivity and motor strength on the inferior limbs
secondary_outcome.description: AIS (ASIA Improvement Scale) degree on the ASIA score will be assessed in order to evaluate sensitivity and motor strength on the inferior limbs.
The patients will undergo urodynamic study to evaluate urological improvements.

secondary_outcome.measure: Improvements in sensorial mapping and neuropathic pain
secondary_outcome.description: The patients will be submitted to specific questionnaires and clinical examinations in order to evaluate improvements in sensorial mapping and neuropathic pain.

intervention.description: Mesenchymal stem cell transplantation through percutaneous injection.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Closed spinal cord injury at thoracic or thoracolumbar level bellow T8, or open spinal cord injury, at the same level, provided that the mechanism of the lesion is a spinal shock, ischemia or hematoma
- ASIA class A
- Signing the written consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Anatomical transection of the spinal cord
- Spinal cord lesion by sharp objects
- Ongoing infections
- Terminal, neurodegenerative or primary hematological diseases
- Osteopathies which determine a higher risc to the bone marrow puncture
- Coagulopathies
- Severe hepatic, renal or heart failure
- Pregnancy or lactation
- Clinical conditions that hinder the percutaneous injection of the cells such as arthrodesis
- Use of metallic implants near vascular structures (such as cardiac pacemaker or aortic prosthesis) which won't allow patients to perform MRI
- Participation in other clinical trial
